quote: "I've set myself to become the King of Pirates... and if I die trying... then at least I tried!"

"Hero? No! We're pirates! I love heroes, but I don't wanna be one! Do you know what heroes are? Say there is a chunk of meat. Pirates will have a banquet and eat it, but heroes will share it with other people. I want all the meat!"
"I have Nakama who're not strong... But I still want them to be with me..!! So I have to be stronger than anybody else... Or I'll lose them all!!!"
"Are we friends? Or are we foes? That kind of thing you decide for yourselves!"
"If you don't take risks, you can't create a future."
"Being alone hurts worse than pain."
Vote up the best quotes from One Piece .

With over 700 episodes under its belt, you better believe that there are some seriously epic One Piece quotes. We've taken a look at some of the best One Piece moments , and extracted sayings, phrases, and one liners that really impacted those scenes. From Whitebeard's speech as he’s about to die - “On his proud back, or in his whole pirate life, there is no scar he got while running away!” to Zoro’s “Not even Death himself can take my life away!" - these are some of the most awesome moments from the anime so far.

Almost every character in One Piece has at least one memorable line, but these ones really stand out as either inspirational quotes that changed the story, or motivational quotes that really shaped a character into who they became. Our heroes, like Luffy, Law, and Nico Robin all have inspiring quotes, but there are also villains on this list as well. Donquixote Doflamingo is by no means a hero but his speech is still one of the best anime speeches of all time.
Vote for your favorite One Piece quotes below.

1 Challenge The Whole World to a Fight Photo: Toei Animation Whitebeard: "It's not you. The man Roger is waiting for, at the very least, Teach, it's definitely not you. Just like there are those who carry on Roger's will, I'm sure someone will appear to carry on Ace's will someday. Even if you extinguish his bloodline, there's no way that their flame will ever burn out. It has been passed downsince ancient times. And in the future, someday, someone will appear, carrying the history of all those decades on his back, and challenge this whole world to a fight. Sengoku, you guys in the World Government, all fear that immense battle engulfing the whole world that will eventually come. I don't care myself, but as soon as someone finds that great treasure, the entire world will be turned upside down. And someone will find it. That day will definitely come sooner or later. One Piece does exist!" 448 votes Great quote?

2 There Is No Scar That He Got While Running Away Photo: YouTube Narrator: "Although he's dead, his body doesn't collapse! And the way he mowed down enemies with wounds all over his body was certainly monstrous. The number of sword wounds he received in this war is indeed two hundred sixty-seven. The number of gun wounds: one hundred and fifty-two! And he was shot by a cannon forty-six times! Yet, on his proud back, or in his whole pirate life, there is no scar he got while running away!" 386 votes Great quote?

Narrator: "Although he's dead, his body doesn't collapse! And the way he mowed down enemies with wounds all over his body was certainly monstrous. The number of sword wounds he received in this war is indeed two hundred sixty-seven. The number of gun wounds: one hundred and fifty-two! And he was shot by a cannon forty-six times! Yet, on his proud back, or in his whole pirate life, there is no scar he got while running away!"
3 Not Even Death Photo: Toei Animation Zoro: "There is someone that I must meet again. And until that day… not even Death himself can take my life away!" 413 votes Great quote?
Zoro: "There is someone that I must meet again. And until that day… not even Death himself can take my life away!"

4 Bet on the New Age Photo: Toei Animation Whitebeard: When a man such as you comes back from the East Blue without an arm, anyone would be surprised. To what kind of enemy did you give it? That left arm. Shanks: This...I made a bet, on the new age. 295 votes Great quote?

5 The Ones Before You Are Pirates Photo: Toei Animation Shanks (with gun pointed to this head) - Risk your life on it. Bandit #1 - What? Shanks - With that pistol, you risk your life. Bandit #1 - What the hell are you talking about? Shanks - This isn't a child's game. Lucky Roo fatally shoots the bandit in the head Bandit #2 - You killed him! Bandit #3 - What unfair bastards! Benn Beckman - Unfair? Don't be so naive. You are not fighting against holy men. Shanks - The ones before you are pirates. Bandit #2 - Shut up! We don't have any business with you! Shanks - Listen, bandits. I can have food or drinks spilled on me, or even be spit at and I'll laugh about it. However, if for any reason you hurt a friend of mine...I won't forgive you! 359 votes Great quote?

Shanks - This isn't a child's game. Lucky Roo fatally shoots the bandit in the head Bandit #2 - You killed him! Bandit #3 - What unfair bastards! Benn Beckman - Unfair? Don't be so naive. You are not fighting against holy men. Shanks - The ones before you are pirates. Bandit #2 - Shut up! We don't have any business with you! Shanks - Listen, bandits. 6 Have You Ever Seen a Pirate Laughing on the Execution Stand? Photo: YouTube Smoker: “Why was he laughing? Did he know that he would survive? No. That's impossible. He realized that he would end his life here. He admitted the truth that he would die and laughed. Have you ever seen a pirate laughing on the execution stand?” 305 votes Great quote?

Fan-favorite Roronoa Zoro is one of the best characters in One Piece, and fans love the witty, tough, and enduring dialogue he spouts off.
With that reputation, it would seem unlikely for this guy to be waltzing around with words of wisdom, correct? Don't underestimate him.
Even though he started My Hero Academia without a Quirk, Deku was full of determination, as proven by these inspiring quotes in the anime.
The world of One Piece is certainly unique, but there's a lot about it that doesn't make much sense.
While One Piece's Roronoa Zoro has changed quite a bit during his time with the Straw Hats, some things have remained the same.
One Piece may have been running forever but there's still a lot of things we want to know about the lead character, Monkey D. Luffy.
Armin is one of Attack On Titan's greatest heroes, though he may not seem like it at first, but what else are fans missing?
What was better and what got worse after the Time Skip on One Piece?
Though Gon Freecss is clearly a fantastic anime character, there is no denying there have been times when he annoyed fans of Hunter X Hunter.
Despite being a wonderfully written character, there are some things about Mikasa that don’t make sense.
Mikasa is one of Attack on Titan's most popular characters for a reason. These crazy facts will make you understand just why she's so popular.
Both Edward and Alphonse are both great characters in the anime Fullmetal Alchemist ー but which one is ultimately the better brother?
One of Hunter x Hunter's main characters in the manga & anime, Leorio has moments when he is both underrated & overrated.
Edward can often go overlooked by anime fans. But there are also things about him that make him a little overrated.
Sanji, the seeker of the All Blue has some of the most profound dialogue. Here are some of the best quotes from this One Piece chef.
One Piece saw a pretty dramatic time skip that affected a lot of characters. Here's a look at some ways Nami changed (and ways she stayed the same).
Ever since the two-year time skip in One Piece, the Straw Hats have undergone many changes, physically and mentally, namely, the captain.
These megadeus’s are giant mechanical beings, with unparalleled power. They say some of them contain the memories of what happened 4o years ago
Throughout the series, the captain of the Straw Hat Pirates has gone above and beyond the call of duty for his crewmates.
Which villains can Midnight takedown? Which Pro Heros does she stand a chance against? Find out how your favorite My Hero Academia hero would do!

Storytelling is one of the most powerful forces in history. A great story can influence culture and shape a generation's worldview to new and radical ideas. While great stories can come from any medium, no one can deny that anime in particular has had a profound impact on its viewers.
RELATED: The 10 Most Wholesome One Piece Ships, Ranked

In the anime world, One Piece stands at the top as one of the most successful, beloved, and long-running franchises in history. With over a thousand episodes, One Piece is filled with iconic quotes that have shaped fans into better, kinder, and more determined human beings.

One of the strongest, most potent themes in One Piece is the idea of found family. Very few characters in the anime are related, and yet so many strong bonds are formed that crews like the Straw Hats often feel familial.

This quote by Whitebeard emphasizes that theme. It also shows that even in one of the largest and most powerful crews in the world , these pirates are still just members of one big family. While Whitebeard's time in the anime was short, his legacy will live on in the hearts of fans through quotes like these.

While the Skypiea Saga is controversial in the One Piece fandom, no one can deny that Enel is one of the most terrifying villains in the anime's history , both in terms of raw power and destructive mindset. Enel truly believed he was a god and had more than enough strength to back up his claim.
RELATED: 10 Things One Piece Ripped Off From Other Anime
He ruled with intense fear and had Luffy not been his perfect counter, that fear would've held the innocent people of Skypiea with an iron grip for Enel's lifetime.

Throughout its long history, One Piece has had an impressively progressive record in terms of social politics. Some of the most beloved and important characters in the franchise push political boundaries and strive for positive growth and change.

This quote from Bon Clay has a deep impact on many young viewers watching One Piece . It teaches fans that above all, human beings deserve respect, no matter what their personal identity is. With this line, Bon Clay promotes positivity and tolerance that is sorely needed in today's society.

One of the most beautiful and devastating arcs in One Piece centers around Nico Robin's desire to live. As a young child, Robin was forced to flee from society or risk being imprisoned for life or worse. She saw life in its most cruel form and lived decades knowing that only suffering awaits.
By the time of this arc, Robin was truly hoping to die. But it was this quote by Franky that pushed her to realize the beauty of life and that, no matter how hard, it is something worth fighting for.

Blackbeard is one of the most important and intimidating villains in One Piece history, yet his introduction was much more subtle and lowkey than any fan could've possibly expected. Despite being an endgame opponent for the Straw Hat crew, Blackbeard was introduced as one of the few pirates on an island who empathized with Luffy's drive to find Sky Island.
RELATED: One Piece: Ace's 10 Best Quotes
Much like Luffy, Blackbeard believes in the power of dreams. While he may take a villainous approach to his own dreams, one can't help but respect his unwavering will.

Dr. Hiriluk may have died before the series ever began, but One Piece fans still love him all the same. Through his wacky personality and beautiful idealism, he was a massive influence on Chopper and was the source behind many of the reindeer's most lovable character traits.

This quote not only works extremely well in the context of Hiriluk's fate in the anime but also as a beautiful way of thinking about death in real life. Dr. Hiriluk's idea of life brings comfort to any fan who may be going through a difficult time with the passing of a loved one.

While many shonen anime portray different types of stories with their own unique themes, some messages transcend their individual anime and become a staple of the genre. Any great battle shonen promotes the idea that hard work and determination are the keys to success and One Piece is no different.

While not everything can be overcome with just effort, working hard is still the number one thing that any individual can do regardless of their obstacle's difficulty. This is an ideology that Luffy has lived by his entire life.

Chapter one of One Piece has one of the most powerful, story-defining moments in the medium's history. Shanks is an archetypical mentor in many ways, providing Luffy with the motivation and goals that would frame the entire anime. But where Shanks differs from many other badass mentors is his approach toward civility.

Despite being one of the most powerful figures in One Piece history and someone that should be feared in most regards, Shanks demonstrates in that first chapter that humility is key and violence is only necessary to protect one's friends.

Over the years Luffy has done a lot to solidify himself as one of the most iconic and admirable protagonists in battle shonen history. While many recognize him for his aloof and goofy personality, Luffy is actually defined by his sheer determination and perseverance in becoming the greatest pirate to ever live.
RELATED: "Believe In The Me That Believes In You" & 9 Other Inspirational Quotes From Anime
Luffy has no understanding of what it means to give up on his dreams. While things may seem impossible, that has never stopped Luffy from trying and that is embodied by this quote.

Throughout its 1000+ episodes, One Piece has consistently branded itself as a story about fun and adventure, but being whimsical doesn't prevent the anime from occasionally dipping into some profound wisdom. One Piece is an inherently political story that has a lot to say about the world.

These ideas are often embodied by the anime's more radical characters, such as Luffy's father, Dragon. This quote by Dragon has a lot of meaning in today's world, where people are often so driven by greed and power that they're willing to throw away anyone that doesn't serve their goals.
NEXT: 10 Shonen Anime With The Most Meaningful Lessons

One Piece is packed with not just cool worldbuilding and exciting fight scenes, but also some incredible dialogue to bring all these characters and their world to life. Dialogue is often the best way for characters to express themselves and comment on the world they live in, and the best quotes will stick in viewers' minds for many years to come.

One Piece may have plenty of cheap and silly dialogue, such as shouting attack names or friendly banter, but the dialogue isn't all fluff. In every story arc, the best One Piece characters will have something profound or meaningful to say, which often encapsulates exactly who these characters are and what they stand for.
Updated by Alan A. Mehanna, on March 11, 2024: This list has been updated to adhere to CBR's most recent standards for formatting.
If you don't take risks, you can't create a future.
- Monkey D. Luffy, One Piece Clockwork Island Adventure

Protagonist Monkey D. Luffy might blurt out a lot of nonsense in One Piece , but he's not as foolish as his worst dialogue would suggest. Luffy puts more thought into his adventure and his life than many other One Piece characters give him credit for, and his dialogue reflects this. His best quotes also stem from his practical, go-getter ESTP personality type.

Luffy is always working toward the future, and even if he's not a crafty schemer or meticulous planner, he has the right attitude to seize his destiny and make something of himself. Planning and strategy are great, but action and confidence are what turn dreams into reality so a person, pirate or not, can unlock the future they want.
I understand starving people more than anyone.
- Sanji Vinsmoke, Chapter 854

Luffy's chef and crewmate Sanji Vinsmoke often acts self-centered in One Piece , from seeking out the All Blue for his own culinary purposes to chasing after women for his own pleasure. Rarely does Sanji show any sympathy or emotionally support others, but if he meets the right people, he will show them kindness after all.

Sanji's quote about starving people proved that for a tough guy like him, it takes personal experience for Sanji to truly connect with someone and understand their hardships. This harkens back to Sanji's rough experience on that chunk of rock with Zeff, where they nearly died of starvation, and it helps explain why Sanji detests wasting food.
Bring on the hardship. It's preferred in a path of carnage.
- Roronoa Zoro, Episode 300

Roronoa Zoro the swordsman has a tough-guy persona, and he often speaks in terse, harsh ways to express himself and what he thinks of others. This means Zoro has some of the best and coolest dialogue among One Piece 's main characters, including his quote about living a life of challenges and hardship.

Zoro knows that as a pirate serving the future pirate king, his career will be filled with deadly challenges. Instead of fearing that hardship, Zoro embraces it all as a chance to grow stronger and prove himself. Zoro understands that no one, warrior or not, improves themselves when they're comfortable.
One Piece's universe holds many secrets, and the World Government likes it that way – leaving many citizens clueless about the world they live in.
In order to draw a map of the world.

Nami was always fascinated by maps, and she vowed to become a great cartographer who would draw a map of the entire world. Now, Nami can realize that lofty dream as Luffy's navigator, and she applies this philosophy to life in general.

Trying to pay Arlong's debt Nami was always shackled to her home town. After Luffy freed her, she was able to truly explore the world without guilt or pain. A life can be either spent or wasted, but will end regardless, so Nami believes people can and should spend their lives creating something incredible and make their limited time mean something.
Even if there are billows of smoke, we can still see the sky. We can still see the ocean! It ain't like it's hell here! So don't act like you're about to die!

Like his captain Luffy, Usopp the sniper king has plenty of goofy and forgettable dialogue, and he's also prone to telling tall tales , hence his big nose. However, Usopp also has some heartfelt things to say, usually to help motivate his crew and show what a wonderful, caring person he is.

Usopp's line about not acting like someone is about to die is a fairly standard shonen sentiment, but it still means a lot. No one, certainly not a Straw Hat, should give up before they die and deny themselves one last chance to fight back. If someone has lost in their mind, then they will definitely lose on the outside, too.
With declarations of war, and significant timeskips, One Piece plotlines rank among the best that shonen anime has to offer.
I realized that back then, the reason I wanted to become human, was that I really just wanted to have friends. Now, I just want to be a monster that can help Luffy.
- Tony Tony Chopper, Episode 81

Tony Tony Chopper the reindeer made his debut in the Drum Island story arc, as the disciple of the late Dr. Hiriluk and an associate of Dr. Kureha's. Chopper ate a Devil Fruit to be more human, including talking and walking upright, but when he met Luffy, Chopper wasn't afraid to be his original self.

Chopper found acceptance and validation with Luffy's crew, so he no longer tried so hard to hide his monster side. Chopper felt free to use his Rumble Balls to become a great shaggy beast who can pummel his enemies for Luffy's sake, and that kind of self-acceptance means a lot coming from an animal who rejects being his actual species.
You know, kid, laughter is the key to happiness. When you’re happy, you laugh. So it follows that you’ll become happy when you laugh… Try laughing. When times are tough, just laugh!

Nico Robin is a clever, independent-minded kuudere who joined the Straw Hat crew as the Alabasta arc ended. For a time, Robin kept her true feelings and past life to herself as a mysterious Straw Hat, but eventually, One Piece fans learned the truth. Nico Robin had been through a lot, and it almost broke her.

Robin was ready to give up and handed herself over to the World Government at Enies Lobby to save her friends, but then she was inspired to survive after all. Nico Robin's emotional resilience is expressed well in her quote about hard times, since laughter is indeed the best medicine. It can refresh the mind and give someone the resolve and willpower to face their hardships once again.
Vegeta is one of the most iconic characters in the Dragon Ball franchise, and some of his best lines can be found in Dragon Ball Super.
The government says your existence is a crime, but no matter what kind of weapons you may hold, just being alive isn't a sin! There's no crime in living!

The cyborg shipbuilder Franky, like Luffy and Usopp, tends to have a lot of silly dialogue for the sake of comic relief throughout One Piece . Still, Franky can be serious if he sees fit, such as his quote to Nico Robin in the Water 7 saga 's climax at Enies Lobby.

Franky's line was most resonant for Nico Robin, who felt like a criminal just for being a well-read scholar from Ohara, but it can apply to anyone. Even if someone has made past mistakes or comes from a rough place, their past does not make them a bad person, and they can always find new ways to validate themselves in the present.
Being dead is never an apology.

Brook the musical skeleton often talked about death and bones for obvious reasons, sometimes for humor's sake and sometimes to say something profound. Brook has a unique view on death and the afterlife, having already died once, and he's determined to not glamorize death for any reason.

Brook highly values life and can't stand it when people choose to embrace death instead. For example, Brook noted that a person's death cannot make things right, and a person cannot make up for their past wrongs by ending their lives. Death won't erase what happened, and even if the dead person's enemies are satisfied, it's an empty satisfaction.
- Portgas D. Ace, Episode 483

Luffy's brother, Portgas D. Ace, didn't get much familial love growing up in the Goa Kingdom, so instead, he embraced Sabo and Luffy as his brothers. Then Ace grew up and embarked on his pirating adventure, and he only saw Luffy a few more times until his death. But even if the brothers were often kept apart, their bond remained strong.

During the climax of the Summit War saga at Marineford, Ace suffered a mortal blow and knew he didn't have long. So, he held Luffy one more time and said what always meant to say: to thank Luffy for being his loving brother. That allowed Ace to pass in peace, and he even died with a smile on his face, as per the Will of D .
Mayumi Tanaka Monkey D. Luffy (voice)
Kazuya Nakai Roronoa Zoro (voice)
Follows the adventures of Monkey D. Luffy and his pirate crew in order to find the greatest treasure ever left by the legendary Pirate, Gold Roger. The famous mystery treasure named "One Piece".
From the beginning, One Piece has tried its best to avoid meaningless episodes, but even this shonen masterpiece has filler content worth skipping.
The world of One Piece is home to a vast array of interesting characters. Among these characters, a few stand out as definite fan favorites.
Over the years, Luffy has gained access to several forms to combat his opponents at different times and overcome them with all his might.
Eiichiro Oda's One Piece has become an anime classic, but it started as a popular manga with some impressive art throughout its decades-long run.
Portgas D. Ace is one of One Piece's most beloved characters. Though he left too soon, his legacy lives on in the series and fans' hearts.
A sound power system has become a must in any shonen series, but none are as full of zaniness as the Devil Fruits from One Piece.
Haki is an important power in the world of One Piece, and only a select number of the Straw Hat Pirates can use it.
One Piece's Luffy has a distinctive voice in both English and Japanese, but fans of these characters may be shocked to know they share the same VA.
One Piece teams up with Rubik's Cube for a stunning six-sided tribute to Monkey D. Luffy, starring all five of the hero's iconic "Gear" forms.
One Piece, by Eiichiro Oda, has so many episodes and chapters that many of its mysteries have been abandoned or forgotten about by its creator.
One Piece has one of the largest and most varied casts in anime, and its core crew, The Straw Hats, are equally diverse when it comes to their ages.
Toei Animation's One Piece anime partners with Uno for an all-new deck starring Gear 5 Luffy, which is set to be available for purchase worldwide.
The friendships between Luffy, Zoro, and the rest of the Straw Hat Pirates are some of the best parts of One Piece.
The Straw Hat Pirates have faced tough times on more than one occasion and despite being more than a family, they've had to lose a bunch of members.
Chapter 1058 of One Piece, "New Emperors," finally confirmed all of the Straw Hat Pirates' bounties coming out of Wano, and they saw major increases.
Monkey D. Luffy's journey is unlike any other character on the Straw Hat crew. Being the protagonist allows Luffy to grow into a god.
Throughout One Piece, the Straw Hats have dared to challenge legendary figures, but they often overestimate their own abilities and pay for it.
One Piece's fight between Monkey D. Luffy and Rob Lucci was an epic battle that had a surprising outcome for Lucci and the CP0 Agents.
One Piece has released amazing episodes since Luffy awakened his Gear 5 form, and the series is ramping up for an even more thrilling final saga.
The Supernovas refers to a group of Pirates in One Piece who arrived at Sabaody Archipelago with a bounty of at least 100 million, here's our ranking.

Portgas D. Ace is one of One Piece's most influential and memorable characters. He immediately became a beloved character due to his suaveness and care for Luffy. His many memorable quotes further contributed to his popularity. His protective streak was quickly made apparent, but he also had unexpected manners. Flashbacks to the past also showed how he changed from being annoyed with Luffy to them becoming brothers.

While on his journey to the New World, Ace consumed the Flame-Flame Fruit and joined the Whitebeard Pirates. Ace was then the commander of the Whitebeard Pirates' second division. His powerful abilities and position with one of the strongest pirate crews in the pirate world made him a renowned force. The reactions of others upon meeting him solidified his reputation among characters throughout One Piece and fans. Additionally, Ace has quite a few quotes about his dedication to living life without regrets, which speak to the mindset that enabled him to get so strong.

Updated on May 10, 2025, by Natasha Elder: One Piece is full of remarkable characters, but Ace manages to outshine many. Fans immediately fell in love with his simultaneously laid-back personality and dangerous air. It is thus no surprise that he has many notable quotes throughout his time on-screen. Accordingly, this list is updated with more of his best lines and to reflect CBR's current publication standards.
See this tattoo? That's our mark. And it's my pride.

There are many fearsome and memorable pirate crews in One Piece , but the Whitebeard Pirates still managed to stand out. The fact that the captain is one of the Four Emperors of the Sea immediately indicates their strength. More than that, the Whitebeard Pirates are like the Straw Hats in that their bond as crewmates makes them family. This Ace quote alludes to how much being part of such a tight-knit crew means to him .
Every once in a while, a character makes a profound statement that captivates the audience. In One Piece, there's no shortage of inspirational quotes.

The tattoo of the Whitebeard Pirates' Jolly Roger that spans Ace's entire back could not be a clearer symbol of his devotion to the crew. This great Ace quote sums up these feelings succinctly. He is proud to be part of the Whitebeard pirates, and wants everyone to know. The fact that he largely goes shirtless further demonstrates how he wants to show off his allegiance to the crew.

When One Piece first introduces Ace, it is unclear what his purpose is. After the Straw Hat Pirates leave Drum Island with Chopper, two men approach Kureha and Doltan, passing on a message about a mysterious man waiting for Luffy in Alabasta. Though Ace soon reveals himself as Luffy's brother, his introduction was more ominous. Still, his "cool guy" aura was interrupted by the fact that he forgot to give his name.
Oh, yes, I forgot about that. The name's Ace, gentlemen. If you tell the Straw Hat pirate, then he'll know who I am.

This goofy moment interrupts Ace's suave aspect, which isn't just humorous. This interaction serves as the first time Ace's name is said, and reveals that he has a history with Luffy, considering that he also mentions Luffy will know his name. Overall, this Ace quote was a great way to inspire intrigue in this new character while simultaneously revealing aspects of his character.

During the Alabasta arc, the Straw Hats were shocked to discover Luffy had a brother, though not quite as shocked as when they found out the formidable Revolutionary Army member was his other brother. More than that, the Straw Hats commented on how polite Ace was compared to his younger brother. The series makes his manners clear several times, one of which is when he says this line.
Nice to meet you and thanks for taking care of my kid brother! I know he's a handful!

Additionally, this quote demonstrates how much Ace cares for Luffy. He knows that Luffy is a bundle of energy and tends not to think before he acts. Correctly, he assumes that Luffy's crew must occasionally compensate for his impulsiveness. Despite these aspects of Luffy's character, his crew and Ace care deeply for the Straw Hat captain. Seeing that Luffy's crew is so reliable means a lot to Ace, so he also truly means it when he says it's nice to meet them.

The most important part of Ace's One Piece journey was his desire to avenge his fallen crewmate after Blackbeard, a member of Ace's 2nd Division, murdered 4th Division Commander Thatch over a rare and powerful Devil Fruit. This need for vengeance is partly because it was disrespectful to Ace as Blackbeard's commander, but also because Whitebeard considers the crew his family and is very hurt by his actions. Ace vowed to hunt Blackbeard down even though Whitebeard said he shouldn't take the risk.

You see, Blackbeard used to be a member of the Second Division of the Whitebeard Pirates. He was one of my own men, but he committed the most unforgiveable sin a pirate could. He killed one of his fellow crewmembers and then he jumped ship. As Commander of his division, it's my responsibility to take care of him.

The fact of the matter is that Ace, while he sometimes appeared to be aloof, cared about honor, specifically, the honor of his position, especially as it related to being a representative of the Whitebeard Pirates. To see one of the men in his command commit such a horrible crime was something that Ace could never forgive, and it was worth paying any cost to try to avenge it. The responsibility that Ace assumes is just further proof of his dedicated personality and how much he cares for those around him.

Like his brother, Ace loved his position as a pirate, and he appreciated Whitebeard for allowing him to be part of his crew. This gratefulness only increases in light of the trouble that Ace repeatedly gave Whitebeard when he was first brought on the ship, trying to kill him on multiple occasions. Even before becoming a member of the Whitebeard Pirates, though, Ace was determined to become one. He had even formed the Spade Pirates when he first started his journey.
I don't owe anything to anyone, not even a god. That's what it means to be a pirate, right?

This iconic statement, Ace, highlights what being a pirate means to him. To Ace, being a pirate means he doesn't have to answer anyone, not even a god, which makes him almost feel like he is on the level of gods . Given his struggles with his lineage and the expectations placed on him by Garp, this feeling of freedom means a lot to Ace.
I won't run.

It almost makes sense that Ace's journey in One Piece ended with his death, as he constantly embraced a "never back down" attitude in his life. He knew that being a pirate meant that he might die, but he was willing to pay that cost if it meant never backing down from a fight. This not only led to engaging fight sequences , but also indicated his indomitable spirit.

Of course, as even Ace knew himself, this was a path that would likely end in his death at some point, but he was comfortable with that cost. He had no illusions about what kind of life he was leading. Despite the fact that injury and death were always possibilities, Ace faced battles head-on. More than that, he sought them out. This Ace quote was spoken when he was a child facing down the pirate Bluejam, and it was a phrase that remained true for the rest of his life. It was ultimately this mentality that led to him fighting Akainu in Marineford at the end.

Ace had a complicated relationship with his biological father, Gol D. Roger. He never met Roger, given the pirate’s execution, but Ace’s association with Roger influenced many of the decisions in his life. In fact, being Roger’s son is one of the reasons that Sengoku wanted to make Ace’s execution such a public spectacle. While broadcasting the scene, Sengoku makes a point of asking Ace who is father is.
The name of my father is Whitebeard.

Rather than giving Sengoku the answer he wanted, and was most likely expecting, Ace quietly but firmly says this piece of dialog. The Whitebeard Pirates are like a family, and Whitebeard makes it no secret that he acts as the father. Over time, Ace came to appreciate Whitebeard’s commitment to those in his crew. As such, he did come to view Whitebeard as his father over time, which is part of why he is so fervently devoted to his crewmates and captain.

Ace and Luffy were very close growing up. Even though they had been separated for a few years when the series began, the two of them remained close. Ace loved his brother, and he admired Luffy's goal of becoming the pirate king even though Ace wanted Whitebeard to achieve that goal. That being said, he felt regret that he wouldn’t be around to see Luffy achieve his dream.
There's only one way to live life, and that's without regrets.

In his dying moments, Ace stressed that one of the most important things to do was to live a life without regrets. While he wished to see Luffy’s dream completed, Ace said he didn’t have any regrets about how he lived his life. Given Ace struggled with the question of whether he should have been born, it was a bright spot in the dark moment of his death that he died without any regrets for his life .

When Ace first arrived in Alabasta, fans knew he was looking for Luffy but didn't know why. As he was walking through a marketplace on his search, one of the salesmen offered Ace a golden apple that would allow him to live 1000 years. Ace quickly let the gentleman know that he's fine living through the day. In retrospect, upon learning about Ace’s conflicted thoughts about whether he should have been born, this statement carries a lot more weight.
Sorry, I'm not interested in living 1000 years. Just living today is good enough.

Furthermore, Ace's response foreshadowed the fun-loving adventurer fans would soon fall in love with . Ace was no stranger to risk-taking actions. He was very aware that his position as the Commander of the 2nd Division of the Whitebeard Pirates made him a valuable target for both Marines and other pirates. Despite this, he loved being a pirate and never hid who he was.

While Ace says he doesn’t owe anything to anyone when speaking with Yamato, he meant it in the sense that no one could tell him how to live his life except for himself. He did acknowledge the sacrifice that others gave for him. His mother, Rouge, extended her pregnancy for twenty months so that the Marines wouldn’t suspect her child to be Roger’s offspring. In doing so, she only lived long enough to name Ace before dying.

We've both got the blood of criminals flowing through our veins, and that was the only gift those bastards ever gave us. I took the name 'Portgas' from my mother because I owe her so much. But I don't owe my father a damn thing. He can keep his name.

This is why Ace chose the surname “Portgas.” He wanted to honor his mother’s sacrifice. At the same time, this acted as just another reason for Ace to hate Roger. Ace’s association with Roger led to others scorning him just for being born, so he felt no need to give any kind of gratitude toward him.
We want to hear from you! Share your opinions in the thread below and remember to keep it respectful.
Your comment has not been saved
This thread is open for discussion.
Be the first to post your thoughts.

Lawrence Marable , a previous Staff Writer at CBR , is a true expert in his field, specializing in in-depth coverage of anime and manga, including titles such as Dragon Ball , One Piece , Dandadan , and Jujutsu Kaisen . With his expertise in narrative analysis and cultural research, he explores thematic depth, character development, and real-world influences. His work, which is both insightful and well-researched, instills confidence in his audience, deepening their engagement and enriching their appreciation.
Spoilers for the One Piece manga's Elbaph arc.

It's not an exaggeration to say that meeting Shanks was the most pivotal encounter Luffy has had with a Roger's Pirate so far in Eiichiro Oda's One Piece . But some fans may not appreciate or understand just how monumental their relationship is. It's clear that with recent chapters of One Piece, Oda is hammering how important Shanks is to Luffy. He has even gone out of the way to show Luffy attacking Loki after the latter insulted Shanks' honor.

Shanks molded Luffy into the man he is today, teaching him how to be a pirate and man and imparting a grand legacy onto Luffy as the inheritor of Roger's will. All of this is monumental, which is why it'll make their eventual clash one of tragedy, but before that clash happens, it's best to familiarize oneself with the bond between Red Hair Shanks and Monkey D. Luffy.

Shanks was found by the Roger Pirates after the God Valley Incident and, since then, became an apprentice of Roger's crew, even inheriting the Straw Hat Roger used to wear. Shanks was loyal to the Roger Pirates crew but didn't follow them to Laugh Tale because Buggy, his fellow apprentice and friend, became ill.

Shanks declared he'd visit Laugh Tale in the future, but on Roger's return, Shanks asked Roger a question that burst the young pirate into tears when he got his answers. After Roger's execution and the disbanding of the Roger Pirates, Shanks would start his own pirate crew. At one point, he met his brother, Shamrock , at Mary Geoise, where he renounced his birthright. Shanks' relationship with Rogers is significant as the Straw Hat became an essential treasure to him.
While One Piece characters like Monkey D. Luffy are known for their bravery, Straw Hats like Usopp and Zoro help redefine exactly what courage means.

Thirteen years before the start of the series, Shanks stole the Gomu Gomu no Mi from a ship being guarded by CP9. Many theories believe Shanks was aware of the Gomu Gomu no Mi's actual name and nature after his adventures on Elbaph and learning about Nika, and specifically hunted down the fruit to give it to Ace , Roger's son, who Roger believed would find the One Piece and surpass him.

Shanks likely believed similarly, having such a fondness for Roger. That is until Shanks met Luffy on Dawn Island by accident. Shanks describes Luffy said something similar to Roger's that practically changed his whole trajectory and made him stay on Dawn Island and Foosha Village for a year.
In the East Blue, there's a kid saying the exact same thing as Captain Roger! The very same words the Captain said! — Shanks

Seeing Roger’s will in Luffy, Shanks grew close to him, even celebrating when the boy stabbed himself to prove his worth. However, he refused to let Luffy join his crew because of his inexperience. Shanks’s care deepened after Luffy ate the Gomu Gomu no Mi, even sacrificing his arm to protect him. When Shanks left, Luffy vowed to become a pirate, gather a crew, and surpass him as Pirate King. Smiling, Shanks gave Luffy his Straw Hat—a promise that remains unfulfilled.

Luffy sees Shanks as his role model and the Straw Hat as his most critical treasure, and he defends the hat no matter what. This relationship goes both ways, as Shanks is constantly impressed and wowed by Luffy's growth. He discusses him with figures like Whitebeard, Ace, and his former Roger Pirates, Rayleigh and Gaban. Through watching and growing up around Shanks, Luffy was also imparted with tremendous wisdom that turned him into the man he is today.

For example, Shanks believed that any insult to him didn't matter, even if it resulted in physical pain or perceived humiliation. This is seen when Higuma pours drinks on him in Fooscha Village, while Luffy is at first confused about why Shanks would simply let Higuma have his way with him, but Shanks simply sees Higuma as nothing to get worked up over.

That is until Higuma threatened Luffy, and Shanks was more than willing to get involved and show Higuma the difference in their power. Luffy carries on this mature mindset by never starting a fight unless a friend's pride or self is hurt. He did the same against Bellamy , who underestimated the Straw Hat, and Tama, who hit and badmouthed Luffy after she was told about Ace's death. Luffy never got mad at her since the insults were about him and not a friend.

Shanks made Luffy a wiser man than many give him credit for. He could accurately tell whether someone was evil, understand their most significant obstacle in Alabasta, and make an enemy of the World Government to help Robin understand that he's willing to share her burden. Luffy has always had a knack for understanding others and gauging the best way to approach things emotionally, just like Shanks has.

Some of Luffy's best quotes come from his wisdom fostered by Shanks. Shanks has also taught Luffy how to be a pirate, and while Luffy's approach to freedom seems to be an innate trait, Shanks has continued fostering it by presenting examples of what a pirate should be. Partying and enjoying life with his crew rather than pillaging and harming others for no reason.

The Straw Hat is one of the most essential accessories in One Piece . And as it was passed down from Rogers to Shanks and now to Luffy, it carries all three's pursuit of freedom. The Straw Hat represents the freedom to pursue one's dreams and a physical representation of Roger's will. Roger passed it onto Shanks to give Shanks the freedom to pursue his dream, and similarly, Shanks is giving Luffy the freedom to pursue his dream, a dream that will see him become the next Joyboy.

The Straw Hat also represents a "pirate king's crown." It's a simple headpiece worn on top of someone's head but made of straw and pauper. Thanks to its connection to Roger, it signifies kingship. Another unique trait of the Straw Hat is its color, as it's as close to gold as a hat can be, and with its dome appearance, it almost looks like a golden sun.

It perfectly represents Luffy becoming the Sun God as the hat is now more closely associated with him and his crew rather than Shanks or Roger despite them both wearing it. The Straw Hat is the last connection Shanks has to Rogers, which makes the inevitable collision course the two are on even more tragic.

Shanks and Luffy are on a collision course for the One Piece, and they will likely collide either at the location on the final island or on the path there. Luffy did remark that one day, he'd assemble a crew strong enough to take on Shanks and become King of the Pirates, and that moment is coming closer than one may think.

Shanks goes for the One Piece at the end of Wano and attacks Bartalameo, which proves that he sees Luffy not only as a legitimate pirate but also as a fellow emperor of the sea. The anime series may surprise fans by making Shamrock a figurative battle between Shanks and Luffy, but the real tragedy lies in Luffy facing Shanks himself. He may have to fight his mentor and give up the Straw Hat—the symbol of his dreams and crew. Their clash will be monumental and could become one of One Piece’s greatest battles as the iconic shonen series ultimately comes to a close.

The world of One Piece is filled to the brim with hundreds of uniquely peculiar characters, but none are more memorable than protagonist Monkey D. Luffy. Over 27 years, he has left an indelible mark on not only the Grand Line but the entire animanga medium, gaining a reputation as one of the most beloved characters in shōnen anime history. More importantly, Luffy's adventures are still ongoing, making him even more relevant today than ever.

Although Monkey D. Luffy isn't always the most eloquent character, he's still spawned a variety of memorable quotes during his time as a pirate. His moral compass and free spirit are much-needed additions to the jaded world of One Piece . And thanks to his well-traveled nature, his words often give life to many of the ideals that the World Government tries to suppress.

Updated on April 24, 2024, by Natasha Elder: Despite seeming like a relatively simple character, Luffy has many inspirational moments throughout One Piece. His determination to do right has resulted in motivational quotes and apt reminders of what's important. As the Egghead arc continues on in animation, we thought it fitting to return to discuss more of Luffy's best quotes, provide accuracy in explaining why this Luffy dialogue is so great, and update imagery to show his best moments.

Since the beginning of One Piece , Luffy has been working toward a singular goal: finding the titular treasure and becoming the King of the Pirates. Despite his focus on personal agency and freedom, even the Straw Hat captain realizes that he cannot accomplish his dreams alone. Luffy very rarely expresses his fear of being unable to become the Pirate King, so this quote hits extremely hard.
Without you, I won't… I can’t become the Pirate King!!

Luffy's heartfelt declaration severely affects Sanji, who breaks into tears, and a sobbing Sanji is completely out of character for him. Then again, it makes complete sense why Luffy would say such a thing, especially with Sanji as his unofficial left-hand man. Having fought together as often as they have, Sanji's assistance is crucial for Luffy finding the One Piece, and, more importantly, Luffy has a deep bond with each of his crewmates . This quote also applies to the rest of the Straw Hat Pirates, all of whom are necessary components of each other's successes.

Determination is one of the traits that most defines Luffy’s character. While he is often so cheerful it is easy to forget his strength, Luffy becomes quite formidable once he gets serious. This memorable Luffy quote from One Piece: Stampede perfectly sums up his line of thought. He is going to come out on top of anyone that stands between him and his goal to become the King of the Pirates.
If your goal is to become the King of the Pirates, then I refuse to lose to you!

This single-minded determination is an important reminder to fully commit to one’s dream. There will always be difficulties in pursuing ambitious goals, whether it comes from direct competition or indirect obstacles. Remaining confident in one’s own ability to overcome these difficulties is paramount in order to eventually succeed. This Luffy quote thus serves as a succinct reminder to not be deterred when encountering opposition .

Freedom is one of the prime reasons that Luffy wants to become the King of the Pirates. The idea of being free has also defined his relationship with his crewmates. From freeing Zoro from the corrupt Marines to freeing Robin to say she wants to live, Luffy has helped his crewmates escape from their bounds throughout One Piece . That is why this inspirational quote is so fitting for the Straw Hat captain.
If that's so, try controlling me!

In One Piece Film: Gold , Gild Tesoro is obsessed with gold due to his tragic experiences as a slave. He believes that gold controls everything and, with his gold-based Devil Fruit, he is the rightful authority. Luffy dares Tesoro to try to control him in response. The context in which this quote is said makes it even better, because it is not only a reminder of autonomy; it is also a reminder that no amount of wealth makes someone better than others. It one’s character that truly defines worth.

Luffy’s final confrontation with Enel takes place during one of the best episodes in the Skypiea arc . This quote is one of the things he shouts at Enel before finally ending the fight for good. While Luffy gets in a lot of confrontations throughout the show, and is not shy to say what he believes, this quote stands out because of the significant context that goes along with it. Beating Enel and ringing the bell doesn’t help just him, the Skypieans, and the Shandia, but also fulfills Mont Blanc Cricket’s dream.
You're next! I'll ring you along with the bell!

The confidence with which Luffy says this quote is truly amazing. Despite all the power that Enel has, Luffy has no doubt that he’ll achieve his goals. More importantly, even in the midst of a life-and-death battle, Luffy is prioritizing his promise to Mont Blanc Cricket. This is how highly Luffy thinks of others’ dreams. By combining his determination to beat Enel with his belief in the dreams of others, Luffy managed to gain even greater strength in his fight.

Luffy believes in his crew to take care of themselves, but that doesn’t mean that he won’t get protective over them. In One Piece Film: Strong World , the antagonist Shiki blackmails Nami into working for him. He has displayed a vast amount of power and a particular disdain for the East Blue. With this combination, he proves to be a significant threat to the ocean that houses Nami’s, Luffy’s, Zoro’s, and Sanji’s family and friends.
I will never let you touch my crew or the sea for as long as I live!

During his final confrontation with Shiki, Luffy loudly proclaims this quote before hitting Shiki so hard that the antagonist mentally compares Luffy to Gol D. Roger . The protection that Luffy displays is admirable. Despite being a pirate, he is determined to save not only his crewmates, but also his home. It is this caring nature that makes Luffy such an endearing protagonist, as well as one that is easy to root for.

“Give it all you got!” is not exactly a new concept. That doesn’t mean that the quote isn’t still sound advice, though. The Straw Hats often find themselves in situations where giving their all is critical to winning. Luffy in particular leaves it all out on the line when he fights. One of the clearest examples of this is the end of his Thriller Bark arc fight against Gecko Moria, where he collapses after winning because of how hard he battled.
Alright, you guys! Give it all you've got!

In One Piece Film: Red , the Straw Hat Pirates and the Red Hair Pirates work together to save Shanks’ daughter, Uta. It is a combined crew effort, and both Luffy and Shanks encourage their crews with the same “give it all you got” sentiment. Sometimes, simplicity is all that is needed to fire up others. Additionally, a tried-and-true inspirational quote like this one has stood the test of time for a reason: it succinctly conveys the right motivation.
Monkey D. Luffy and the rest of the Straw Hat crew have impactful quotes that show fans who they are.

During his fight with Charlotte Katakuri, Luffy finds it very difficult to counter his opponent's Observation Haki. Katakuri is capable of Future Vision, allowing him to dodge or bypass Luffy's attacks, at least until the Straw Hat himself begins developing the same ability. Unfortunately, Katakuri is far too strong and easily pummels the hero into near-unconsciousness.

At one point, Luffy collapses on the ground, which is when Katakuri reveals that the Big Mom Pirates know about the Straw Hats' rendezvous point on Cacao Island. For his part, Luffy casually comments that his crew believes in him, or rather his ability to come out victorious, shocking Katakuri. In this simple quote, Luffy expresses just how much he trusts the Straw Hats and vice-versa. No matter how tough the situation can get, the Straw Hats know that Luffy can surpass it.

Flags are symbolic of power in One Piece , which is why Luffy consistently defends the Drum Kingdom flag designed by Dr. Hiriluk, Chopper's mentor and father figure. Meanwhile, the tyrannical King Wapol attempts to seize his former kingdom once again, only for the Straw Hats to prevent him from doing so. Wapol engages Luffy in battle, who remains more or less unaffected by the former King's attacks.
I don't care if you're a king or not. There are things that matter more than power.

At the same time, he orders Wapol not to touch Dr. Hiriluk's flag, stating that his kingship matters less than the safety and happiness of his people. This quote demonstrates not only Luffy's determination to defeat any oppressors but also his philosophy surrounding power. Luffy doesn't seek strength because he wants to be the strongest ; he knows that power only has value when it's used in defense of the oppressed. It's easy to imagine Luffy sacrificing all his power to save his friends, even if it means losing his dreams.

Pirates and other polarizing figures aren’t the only groups to have meaningful flags. It's clear that the World Government's Flag carries the most innate authority in One Piece . The Marines fiercely defend their employers against pirates, but many of them also cause harm to innocent citizens. Luffy innately recognizes the dangers posed by the World Government, although he expresses his indignation indirectly in most cases.
Sogeking... Shoot down that flag.

In Ennies Lobby, the Straw Hat captain effectively declares war on the World Government by ordering Usopp to destroy its flag. This moment was extra impactful because Usopp, whose cowardice would have otherwise prevented him from taking such risks, gladly obeyed Luffy's command. The Marines watching the scene were shocked at the Straw Hats' audacity, but Luffy had already forgotten about the flag and shifted his attention to Robin by that point.

During the Marineford War in One Piece , Luffy was extremely confident that he could save his brother Ace from execution. And yet, no matter how fiercely he fought, he was ultimately heartbroken when Ace sacrificed his life to save Luffy. The Straw Hat captain rapidly fell into a catatonic state upon his brother's death, leaving his allies to rescue him from the battlefield. Jinbe managed to deliver Luffy to Law's submarine before taking him to Amazon Lily.

Luffy's self-pitying behavior during his recovery was admonished by Jinbe. Luffy reacts by trying to start a fight, but Jinbe shuts that down instantly. The future helmsman of the Straw Hats helps Luffy understand that he has not lost everything. This finally reminds Luffy that his beloved friends—nakama without whom he could never sail the Grand Line—are still around. This is also the quote that inspires Luffy to get stronger, leading to the two-year time skip.
